@pippajaygreen Both!

At what point is a 100-word synopsis just a blurb? I fear I did it wrong... 😐
First came the one-page synopsis. Then came the 300-word synopsis. Now I have just seen a requirement for a 100-word synopsis. Gah!
I just hope that, as an author, if anyone ever comes to me about problematic rep I can own it and learn from it. And fix it, if possible.
But just because he didn't find it problematic that doesn't invalidate others' reactions either.
I should say "some gay readers", actually. It was first recommended to me by a gay man...
But I can see why it's problematic for gay readers. I hear what people are saying.
I still have a soft spot for The Song of Achilles and I can see why Miller made the choice to stick with the historical/mythological ending.
As a het (heterocurious?) reader, I have lots of other choices. If I don't want to read sad books, I can easily do so.
What I've learned today is that the difference is that, for gay readers, the tragic death trope is, well, a trope. It's shockingly common.
But if you'd asked me whether that was a problem, I'd have said no because there are plenty of m/f books with tragic endings too.
The Song of Achilles is a good example. I thought it was a beautiful story about m/m love. Yes, the ending is tragic.
As a writer, I don't want to be guilty of inadvertent problematic rep. And as a reader, I don't want to be dismissive of others' hurts.
But, other times, maybe not always. And that's why I try to listen and understand.
I mean, some problems are obvious to anyone who thinks about it for a heartbeat. (Or they should be.)
But it's a good reminder that people outside a particular group aren't always sensitised to poor rep.
Whenever I see a post or a tweetstorm about problematic rep in a book I've previously read and enjoyed, my first reaction is shame.
